reviewText: F.B.I VS Simon Diamon, Johnny Swinger, & Kid Kash: A very boring match that is stopped halfway thru to have a dance contest. I can't believe true ECW fans didnt boo this out of the building, if any even attended this event. The match resumes with F.B.I winning in the end.Too Cold Scorpio VS CW Anderson: Another bore of a match but Scorpio did impress me with some moves he did.Stevie Richards VS PJ Polaco: B.W.O returns & Richards wins via stevie kick in another bad match.Sandman makes his an apperance afterwards & takes out Polaco with one cane shot.3 Way Elimination Match: Brother Runt VS Rhino VS Al Snow, this match was just like the others, very boring. Two eliminations come very quickly & kind of says just end it already.Team 3D VS Kahoneys & Axl Rotten: Joel Gertner does a nice promo before the match. The match itself was a mess with a this is awesome chant during a light saber duel. Kahoneys gets put thru a flaming table to end this decent match.Tommy Dreamer VS Raven in the Final Showdown: I dont know if this is actually the final encounter between this two because i'm sure they've wrestled on various independent shows but final on PPV. I thought this would pull me out of the funk of a so-so card but this match just dragged on. Foley was guest ref but really did nothing.RVD VS Sabu: Jerry Lynn couldn't make it so we get Sabu instead. A very good match as I thought Sabu looked good in his short TNA return.Overall, I love ECW but they need to put these shows to rest. It's fun to see the old gang but the wrestling has just gotten bad. I thank Dreamer for the event. It was a perfect time to do this because most of the ECW originals were out of the WWE at this point in time. The only one missing from here is Shane Douglas but I think he had problems with TNA. Anyways, nothing worth going out of the way for. If you're a diehard fan then I suppose you'd enjoy it. Also, why the hell did the entire show have a blue tint to it? Is there any reason for this?
Title: N/A

reviewText: As much as i truly hate to say it i honestly think the WWEs One Night Stand 2005 was a better show it shouldve been the only reunion show and had that be the end of it all on a high note.Dont get me wrong HardCore Justice was a fun show for what it was worth but for me the only good matches were raven and dreamer and vandam and sabu.The south philly street fight was an awful excuse for a ecw style fight the only saving grace was the apperance of the flaming table other than that it was awful it looked so staged and the light saber battle while really funny was so lame and corny i just imagined the chants that wouldve gotten in the ECW arena,and the brawl between the orignal gangstas and 3D after the match made no sense at all when they just stopped fighting and all hugged?wtf?Other than that the rest of the show was awful the six man tag to open the show with the FBI vs kid kash,simon diamond and jonnny swinger lef me saying why did i even buy this?The 2 cold scorpio vs CW Anderson was decent enough but shouldve went longer(but did include the sickest legdrop ive ever seen)scorpio is the biggest waste of talent in wrestling the guy couldve been one of the greats its beyond me why he never got a major push.Then was the godawful stevie richards and PJ polako(justin credible) it was a snoozer and even the apperance by Sandman after the match was lame,he didnt even cream anyone with the cane he just gave him a russian legsweep with the cane once again WTF!!!!Bascilly to sum it up its worth it for the final two matches but other than that save yourself the time and skip to the south philly street fight for some laughs and start from there.O on a side note did anyone elses copy have a sound difference during the raven dreamer match?But like i said the WWEs shows 2005 and 2006 were alot funner and had better action but that shouldve been the end of it o and another thing about hardcore justice that angered me is TNA censored alot of the fans chants and blurred out anyone flipping the bird really?censorship?TNA had no understanding of what ECW was about this was just a desprate attempt at ratings and a money maker

Title: N/A

reviewText: This in my opinion other than No Surrender and Lockdown 2010, this was one of the best ppv's for TNA this year. So thanks for reading, comment, rate, and all that stuff.F.B.I vs. Kid Kash, Simon Diamond, and Johnny SwingerWell, in my opinion, I missed this match when i watched this ppv, because i was a couple of minuets late, but i heard this was a enjoyable match, had some good moments, and a nice return victory for The "Full Blooded Italions". 3/5Too Cold Scorpio vs. C.W AndersonThis was actually, a good match, even though for the short time of a match it was, it had some nice moments from scorpio, like the double moonsault for the win, and the action overall was just average, but good. 3.5/5Stevie Richards vs. PJ Palaco(Justin Credible or how you spell it)This wasn't my favorite match of the card, i really didn't see the point of it, was just mostly domination from PJ until Stevie hit a huge Stevie Kick out of nowhere to get the win. This was also very funny, especially for the BwO returning with Stevie. 2/5After the match, PJ of course went nuts for losing in his return to Professional Wrestling since ECW went out of buisness. But, Sandman made a huge impact on the ppv and the crowd went nuts, and just took PJ out with like one shot from his handy Kendo Stick.3-Way Dance Elimination matchRhino vs. Al Snow vs. Brother RuntAgain, not one of my favorite matches, but this was enjoyable. Since Al's head came into play at one point(which was hilarious), but, because of all the domination on Runt, i think he was thrown into the crowd like in the ECW days in this match, but, he of course was elminated first, and then i've never seen a bigger gore from Rhino ever after this match on Al. 2.75/5South Phili Street FightTeam 3D vs. Kahoneys and Axl RottenThis, in my opinion, was the second most hardcore matches of night, very good, enjoyable, and all over the place. These guys were in the crowd for about 3 quarters of the match. Until weapons came in, and we saw the huge and very predictable powerbomb through a flaming table to Kahoneys for the win. Also, Team 3D paid respects in this match with there old Dudley Boys Tye-Died shirts. 3.75/5Final Showdown-No disqulification, No Count outsTommy Dreamer vs. RavenThis, was actually, in my opinion, the most hardcore match and the best match of the night. These two had a match coming as soon as Dreamer debuted back at Slamiversary, especially because Raven was still in TNA, so i saw a good match coming soon. But, anyways. This had some great spots, like, the best crossface i have ever seen in my life, instead of dreamer putting his hands over Ravens face, he used barbed wire instead, and the fun moment of when Buelah gets involved, Funny moment if i must say, and then the blood flow was just like all the other matches in ECW, a blood bath. 4.5/5Extreme RulesRVD vs. SabuThis was originally suppose to be Jerry Lynn vs. Van Dam, which really POed me, because that old ass man Jerry got a freakin neck injury. At least he made apperance on iMPACT. But, this actually turned out to be better, when this match was tunred into Van Dam vs. Sabu. This had some very highflying moments, and a nice table spot, where sabu misses, goes through the table, and van dam gets the frog splash for the win. This was good, but not the best match of the night, could have been better, but some people didn't think so. 4/5This was actually a pretty decent ppv in the end, so thanks for reading, Big T returning review. Thanks
Title: N/A

reviewText: In 2006, Vince McMahon decided to bring back the company of ECW as the third brand for his company which from day one recieved heavy mixed responces.  Over time, WWE would slowly remove the elements of the original ECW promotion in favor of their own image & direction to the point where the last original standing in Tommy Dreamer handed in his notice only for WWE to completely drop the brand two months later.  Now fast foward to six months later where TNA decided to give the ECW originals one last chance to make a final tribute to the original company with the Hard Justice PPV being changed to HardCORE Jusice: The Last Stand as this was an attempt to pay a final tribute to the original ECW company as oppossed to how WWE decided to leave the final image of ECW.Now it should be noted that this was strictly an ECW reunion show so nobody in TNA who didn't wrestle for the original company wrestled on this show so that means there was no A.J. Styles, Kurt Angle, Samoa Joe, ect.  Also to avoid copywrite issues with WWE, a few of the wrestlers names were changed and the group of ECW originals were now known as "Extreme Version 2.0" (EV2.0 for short).  There were a bunch of changes to the Impact Zone (called the "Extreme Zone" for this show) as the ramp to the ring was removed, the lighting was changed as the ring was lit with the color blue while the audience was blackened, and there were traces of barbed wire on the stage, and some of the wrestlers had generic versions of their old ECW music while TNA regulars used their own.  Old faces from the original ECW were brought in for the such as ring announcer Steven D'Angeles, former referees such as John Finnegan, and even Atlas Security.  Tazz started the show with a heartfelt speech while Mike Tenay remanded as a commentator for the show as eventhough we wasn't in the original ECW, he was a huge fan as he explained during the show.  Now throughout the night, they had different segments showing respect to ECW's past such as "Where Are They Now" segments showcasing people who weren't at the show (Tod Gordon, "Pitbull" Gary Wolfe, Blue Meanie, Francine) giving their final goodbyes while TNA stars talked about their favorite ECW moments (A.J. Styles on the Sandman/Tommy Dreamer cane match, Matt Morgan working at a bar where ECW once held a show, how ECW inspired Chris Sabin, the time Kaz was able to get a workout with the talent early in his career) while tributes were done to Paul Heyman & Joey Styles.  Also this review is strickly of the PPV event itself, I currently have no details about the extra material on the DVD itself.Full Blooded Italians (Guido Maritato, Tracy Smothers, Tony Luke) vs. Kid Kash, Simon Diamond, Swinger - Big Sal E. Graziano accompanied to the ring and wow, he lost tons of weight since the last time he was seen.  This was filled with familiar moments & spots from Simon "having a problem", doing the traditional dance off against Tracy Smothers, and Kid Kash's famous over the top rope flip dive onto everyone outside along with everyone involved in a tower of doom.  This was a fun opening match.Around here was a backstage segment with Stevie, Al Snow, and the return of "Head" that was funny as they poke fun at some of the copywrite issues & old gimmicks to the point where Al asked Stevie "Do you know a good therapist?"2 Cold Scorpio vs. C.W. Anderson - I believe this was the first time 2 Cold has been on national television in the United States I believe since a decade ago & the first time I've seen him period since the Hardcore Homecoming show 5 years ago.  He was very athletic here as if he didn't miss a step since we've last seen him doing various high flying moves as a a corkscrew dive onto the outside, a bodyblock, his famous moonsault off the top rope, and the backflip leg drop twice.  While Anderson didn't do much in the match, it was a great showcase for Scorpio.Stevie Richards vs. P.J. Polaco (Justin Credible) - Stevie came to the ring with his former partner in crime "Hollywood Nova" and another guy called "The Blue Tilly" who was explained in the earlier backstage segment.  He wasn't ment with a well reception as the crowd chanted "We Want Meanie."  This was a solid match but nothing special as it was what happened after the lights went out that was the highlight of this match.Rhino vs. Brother Runt (Spike Dudley) vs. Al Snow - The traditional "3 Way Dance" returns here and for those who don't remember, this is elimination rules where two people have to be eliminated to declare a winner.  This was a fun match with some funny moments like starting off with the 3 way headlock spot along with later doing a unique twist on a spot that was made famous by the late-Eddie Guerrero.  Again, another fun match.Street Fight Match: Team 3D (Dudley Boyz) vs. Axl Rotten & Kahoneys (Balls Mahoney) - Team 3D came down to the ring in their classic look with tie-dye shirts, no music, and even brought along Joel Gertner who did what he did best...a dirty sexual promo.  This was exactly what you would expect from the past of these two teams in a street fight as they brawled all over the place from the ring to the floor & throughout the crowd.  Weapons were used such as a "Head", frying pan, cookie sheet,  dueling fights with chairs & Star Wars lightsabers (yes, you read that right), and of course a flaming table.  This was a fun brawl with a special suprise afterwards as appearently they weren't he only hardcore tag team in the building.Tommy Dreamer vs. Raven w/Mick Foley as the special referee - This was built up as "the final encounter" between both men as this is suppost to be the last time they will ever wrestle each other with Tommy Dreamer's real-life wife & the former "Beulah" was sitting at ringside with their two daughters.  As you expect, this was a hardcore battle from start to finish with some of their trademark spots relived like the "Dead End Sign", Dreamer's Tree Of Woe dropkick in the corner, both men pulling off the drop toehold into the chair & bleeding buckets.  A ladder came into play along with interference from various people (including one guy who was so irrelevant that the crowd gave him a "Who Are You?" chant), Dreamer at one point delievering a vicious crossface on Raven who's face was wrapped in barbed wire, and Dreamer delievering a move with his hands cuffed behind his back that caused Mike Tenay to say, "That's the damnest thing I've ever seen!"  For this being their final encounter, they went out with a bang as this was one of the best matches from both Dreamer & Raven in recent memory.Rob Van Dam vs. Sabu - This was suppost to be RVD vs. Jerry Lynn for the first time in almost a decade but Lynn injured himself training for this match so the decision was made for Sabu (now sporting a bald head) to replace him.  We got a special treat here with Bill Alfonzo returning to manage both men & "call it right down the middle DADDY!" as we saw in the opening moments with Fonzie throwing a chair inbetween both men for them to fight over it along with later doing a comedic "water break" for both men.  We saw various moves such as Sabu using the chair to do a springboard dive into the crowd onto RVD, RVD moneyflipping Sabu onto a chair that ended up having Sabu hit his elbow, Sabu throwing a chair onto RVD on the top rope before delievering a jumping frankensteiner that launched RVD onto the chair, the classic spot where Sabu was strattled on the top rope & Fonzie put a chair infront of his face for RVD to jump off the top rope & kicked the chair into his face, and of course a table getting involved in the action as well.  I concider this to be RVD's best match since coming to TNA.In the end, this event did showcase various elements that made the original ECW promotion have the cult following that it did with some nice wrestling, entertaining moments (some more than others as I could have did without the "replacements" for the original characters who couldn't make the show), wild brawls & violence, and crowd participation.  If you put all the controversy & politics to the side (ahem...Shane Douglas!) along with not having unrealistic expectations of these guys to be as good as they were a decade ago since some of them have sense been either retired or rarely wrestling anymore & just take the event for what it was as a retro trip/reunion show & a nice way for some to say goodbye to ECW they way the felt like it should be done then this is definately an enjoyable event with the only downfalls being that TNA tried too hard to make the production "gritty" to the point where it just came off looking bad such as the lighting.  I would normally give this event a 3.5 but I'll bump it up to a four & I would recommend.
summary: The Last Stand For The Extreme

reviewText: TNA went extreme for one night only in 2010 when they let the originals of extreme have their own PPV. If you loved ECW and this is the DVD for you. Raven vs. Dreamer was an awesome bloody good time and you can never go wrong with RVD vs. Sabu! well worth the price and hopefully when TNA does there Hardcore Justice 2 PPV is 2013 it can live up this show!!
Title: N/A

reviewText: One company, three letters ECW, this company brought an aggressive hardcore edge to wrestling that lead to there being an outcry for this brand of wrestling to return even after the doors shut in early '01. WWE bought the rights to the company and the video library and produced the massively successful documentary "The Rise and Fall of ECW" in '04.WWE listened to the fans and brought ECW back to PPV in '05 with One Night Stand and then another One Night Stand in '06. Sadly then ECW was brought to Sci-Fi and slowly killed off anything that fans remembered from it especially after it went PG thanks to a certain event from a certain wrestler that nearly killed wrestling for good.But thats another story, TNA decided to bring back ECW but do to copyright reasons they couldn't use said letters and labeled this PPV Hardcore Justice and it paid homage to ECW while being a good show on its own merit.The show opens with a series of pictures of ECW originals like Tommy Dreamer, Raven, Team 3D, RVD and others as they talk about how they dont look like stereo-typical wrestlers but that they were part of a revolution known as ECW and how tonight is their last stand.-Taz comes out and cuts a promo basically slamming the haters of ECW and WWE for what they did to the company's legacy.-FBI (Tracy Smothers, Little Guido, Tony Luke w/Big Sal.) vs. Kid Kash, Simon Diamond & Johnny Swinger: Obviously some of these guys aren't in prime shape, as you can tell from looking at Diamond and Smothers. This is a good, but cheesy 6-man tag match, after some good action there's a dance-off between all the men, kinda or rather very sad, but funny. After this the match spills to the outside where Kash hits a great springboard dive onto all 6 including Sal. We also get treated to a tower of doom suplex where Luke gets the worst of it. Guido hits a version of the Killswitch on Diamond for the win. 5/10.-A "Where Are The Now?" video is shown, where Tod Gordon (ECW Founder), Pitbull Gary Wolfe and The Blue Meanie reflect on ECW a bit while thanking the wrestling fans for making them who they are today.-AJ talks about the angle Sandman and Dreamer did where the loser had to be hit with a cane 10 times and how it gave him chills. Angelina Love says she didn't get to see it much in Canada until the last year it was on but the fans just ate it up.-Al Snow is talking to Head and Stevie Richards about how he's scared about the legal action they could be facing for putting on the show. Nova (Simon Dean in WWE) brings in a knock-off of the Blue Meanie (which didn't need to be done in my opinion), Richards said he wants to prove himself tonight. Segment ends with the knock-off and one of Raven's old lackey's trading nose picking (I'm not making that up). Good segment though.-C.W. Anderson vs. Too Cold Scorpio: Pretty good reaction for Scorpio who looked great despite not having been on TV to wrestle in quite a few years. Anderson does spit on Scorpio's hand when offered a handshake and both trade forearm shots. This match was mainly about Scorpio hitting a bunch of highspots though C.W. does get some moves in. Scorpio hits a nice 450 splash into a legdrop from the second rope, but misses a moonsault. Nice moonsault into a legdrop by Scorpio for the win, great move. 6/10.-Madison Rayne talks up how ECW put hardcore wrestling on the map and how they captivated the fans. Matt Morgan and Mr. Anderson also bring up how revolutionary ECW was.-RVD is backstage with Bill Alfonso and they talk about how Jerry Lynn got injured and how Sabu will be taking his place. Side note here: Alfonso sounds horrible.-Stevie Richards vs. P.J. Polaco: Stevie had Nova and Blue Tilly (Blue Meanie knockoff from earlier) & P.J. is of course Justin Credible. This isn't a bad match though the pacing is kinda off at times. Nice splash over the top onto Richards by Polaco, then he works on Richards with punches and chops, before getting sent over the top rope slamming head first into the steel steps. Polaco talks trash and gets the Stevie kick and Richards gets the win. 4/10, pretty short match. Nice aftermath with Polaco using the cane on Richards before the appearance of the Sandman, who canes Polaco in the head.-Another "Where Are They Now?" video is shown, Francine says she would love to be there but she's taking care of her new one year old child. She thanks the fans though.-3 Way Dance: Rhino vs. Al Snow vs. Brother Runt: This is a decent match, nice blend of styles. Runt is of course, Spike Dudley and much like he did in the past he took a beating in this one, he did hit a nice dive then got tossed onto the stage. Snow hits a nice moonsault onto Rhino for a 2 count, Runt attempts the Acid Drop and gets thrown off by Rhino. Nice comedic spot with a chair involving Runt and Snow. Runt hits the Acid Drop on Snow and makes the 3 count, eliminating Snow. Runt then gets hit by the Gore as Rhino makes the cover for the win. 5/10.-Mick Foley is interviewed about being the special guest referee for the Dreamer/Raven match and how this rivalry is very personal and that it will end tonight.-Magnus talks about how the hardcore originals raised the bar for wrestling today and how despite a small budget they had plenty of heart. Chris Sabin said he was hooked from the moment he saw Sabu/Terry Funk in a Barbwire match.-Old School South Philly Street Fight: Team 3D w/Joel Gertner vs. Axl Rotten & Kahoneys: Due to trademark stuff, Kahoneys is of course Balls Mahoney, and like Alfonso from earlier he too sounds horrible. Nice entrance by 3D complete with the classic tye-dye. Gertner does what he does best, a dirty promo, nice shot at Lady Gaga too, also funny moment when 3D stops him from saying the Dudley Boyz (again trademarked by WWE of course). Its a good hardcore tag team match that starts out with on the outside of the ring and spills into the crowd. Weapons are brought out, trash can lids, cookie sheets, chairs, even light sabers at one point where a duel breaks out between Kahoneys and Ray. There is one point where 3D gets hit with a couple of chair shots that look kinda weak. The flaming table it brought out and Kahoneys is slammed through it as 3D gets the win. 8/10. The aftermath though shows there was yet another hardcore tag team in the building as the Gangstas appeare, with New Jack getting a pretty big pop from the crowd. Kinda odd how the brawling just stopped and everyone just hugged.-Raven cuts a promo done in classic ECW Raven fashion, where he talks about his history with Tommy Dreamer.-Jesse Neal says seeing ECW when he was younger helped influence his love and passion to get into the business. Kaz talked about training with some of the hardcore originals when he was just getting into wrestling. Various wrestlers talk about Joey Styles and say thanks to him and wish he was calling this PPV.-The Final Showdown: Tommy Dreamer vs. Raven, Special Guest Referee: Mick Foley: One of the most personal feuds in ECW finally comes to an end tonight. Raven hits the drop toe hold into 2 chairs that busts Dreamer open and Raven starts hammering Tommy. A ladder is brought into play and Raven gets hotshotted head first into it. Dreamer battles back hitting the Dreamer Driver and a drop kick into the corner slamming a sign into Raven's face. Nova and Blue Tilly hit the ring and Tilly misses a splash from the top. Dreamer kicks out of the Raven Effect DDT, Foley and Raven fight and Socko is brought out, then Raven's lackey comes out (getting a "Who Are You?" chant from the crowd). Dreamer at one point gets handcuffed by Raven but somehow pulls off a move that amazes everyone even the announcers. Raven nails the Raven Effect on the chair for the win. 9/10.-Jeremy Borash and So Cal Val are backstage and the Gangstas appear, pretty funny.-Some of the ECW wrestlers talk about Paul Heyman and how he helped a lot of wrestlers become who they are today.-Rob Van Dam w/Bill Alfonso vs. Sabu w/Bill Alfonso: No thats not a typo, as Alfonso will be in both men's corners and play no favorites. This was supposed to be RVD vs. Jerry Lynn but Lynn suffered a back injury while training for the match. These two know each other very well and counter each others moves for the first couple of minutes before Sabu throws a chair at RVD's head. Sabu then hits a springboard dive over the guardrail onto RVD. Sabu attempts a legdrop off the ropes but RVD counters with one of his own. Sabu comes back with a hurricarana from the top rope throwing RVD into a chair on the mat. RVD hits rolling thunder slamming a chair into Sabu, hurting himself also. RVD hits the Five Star Frog Splash for the win. 8/10. Good aftermath with the originals all coming out and celebrating even Brother Ray brings Dixie Carter in on the celebration.Bonus DVD Features-Before The Bell: Done before the show started, this is a documentary style video where various originals talk about ECW and how the fans are clamoring to see this PPV. Its a good one.-The Aftermath: We hear from the wrestlers who competed and appeared on the show and they all reflect on ECW and what it meant to the wrestling business.-Memories: A still photography montage of ECW days from the 90's.-A music video by Black Label Society with footage from Hardcore Justice.-There's also a Q&A; session with Mick Foley and Tommy Dreamer. This isn't a bad segment either.This is worth getting for nostalgic purposes mainly, its a good PPV to see.
Title: N/A

reviewText: The Six Tag Team Match between The F.B.I(Guido Maritato,Tracy Smothers & Tony Luke) against the team of Kid Kash,Simon Diamond & Johnny Swinger was goofy at times but still good in terms of wrestling. The Too Cold Scorpio-C.W. Anderson match was back-and-forth,high-flying,hard-hitting & solid. The Stevie Richards-P.J. Polaco match was also a solid bout mixied with high-flying action,brawling & even comdey with the Big Titty(eeww). The Brother Runt-Rhino-Al Snow 3 way Elimination match was short but still a entertaining & fun match to watch. The South Philly Street fight between Team 3D & The team of Axl Rotten & Kahoneys(F.K.A. Balls Mahoney) was a good reminder of the 1990's ECW and it also bloody,hard-hitting & hardcore and the same goes the Tommy Dreamer-Raven match. The RVD-Sabu(subbing for Jerry Lynn)match was a high-flying,back-and-forth,entertaining brawl. The "Where are they?" & "I Remember" segments were ok. I give this PPV a 7.7 out of 10.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I understand that this ppv was thrown together very quickly and the matches are not bad. It's not a bad attempt at an ECW reunion show . . . but there are a combination of little things that bring it down. Mike Tenay commentating an ECW show instead of Joey Styles. It's in Florida. Can't say ECW. Can't use any ECW trademarks. TNA's bad attempt of putting in a parody of Blue Meanie.But there are some good things. The matches are overall very good, But it does feel like "TNA's attempt at an ECW show" as opposed to an ECW show. And it's impossible to NOT compare it to WWE's One Night Stand 2005. Which is a much better show.The DVD extras also drag this down. Because they have nearly an hour of interviews from ECW stars and 99% of them are about bashing WWE, almost to the point where the DVD is unwatchable.It's decent but it just makes you wish you were watching One Night Stand 2005
Title: N/A

reviewText: I'm not quite sure if it was as good as the WWE One night Stand 05' Reunion Show, but it was pretty damn close. The matches all had really good spots and a bunch of great Wrestlers from ECW past. There were a couple goofy spots, and lulls, and even a dance off between FBI and Swinger & Simon Diamond but otherwise my friends and I really enjoyed it. The ECW Alumni on the DVD consists of, Raven, Dreamer, FBI, Simon Diamond, Johnny Swinger, 2 Cold Scorpio, The Gangstas, Sabu, Taz, RVD, The Dudleys, Spike Dudley, Sandman, Kid Kash, Micky Foley, Rhino, Balls Mahoney, Al Snow, Axl Rotten, and the BWO. It was amusing that they can't say ECW due to Vince owning the name/company and some of the names even are owned so they had to be changed during the matches. They played on it a few times and laughed and made jokes which was kinda cool.I am currently watching the bonus disc as typing this, the interviews are pretty interesting. They aren't really talking about take overs or behind the scenes stuff just yet, it's more hyping someone up about the show they just saw and explaining how ECW changed the game. I'm not sure if we'll see any more reunion shows due to the age and weight of the ECW guys all going up little by little ;) Even though the talent is still there and I always enjoys every one of these guys in action. Worth a look for a nostalgic ECW fan, or even just a wrestling fan in general. Sad that TNA kept some of these guys and just let them go recently. Ex: Raven, Rhino, Sabu etc...Worth a purchase, rental, or steal your friend's disc when he isn't looking lol.
Title: N/A
